title: How to use expertsâ€”and when not to - Noreena Hertz

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with relying too heavily on experts?

options.label: A
options.text: Experts have too much power and influence.

options.label: B
options.text: Experts are not always right, and we need to be more skeptical.

options.label: C
options.text: We have become addicted to experts and have ceded our responsibility for making decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: Experts are not able to process information as well as we can.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the independent decision-making parts of our brains when we listen to experts?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more active and engaged.

options.label: B
options.text: They remain the same.

options.label: C
options.text: They switch off and we become less critical.

options.label: D
options.text: They become more confused and uncertain.

multiple-choice.question: What is one example of how experts can make mistakes, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They may over-prescribe medication.

options.label: B
options.text: They may not consider the perspectives of women when developing new drugs.

options.label: C
options.text: They may not consider the perspectives of different cultures when developing new treatments.

options.label: D
options.text: They may not consider the perspectives of children when developing new policies.

multiple-choice.question: What is one strategy for dealing with experts that the speaker suggests?

options.label: A
options.text: We should always trust their opinions and follow their advice.

options.label: B
options.text: We should be willing to challenge their assumptions and methodologies.

options.label: C
options.text: We should be willing to listen to their opinions, but also be open to alternative perspectives.

options.label: D
options.text: We should ignore their opinions and make our own decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's vision for a more democratic and inclusive approach to expertise?

options.label: A
options.text: That experts should be limited to those with advanced degrees and high status.

options.label: B
options.text: That experts should be limited to those with specialized knowledge and experience.

options.label: C
options.text: That expertise should be democratized and made available to everyone, regardless of background or status.

options.label: D
options.text: That experts should be limited to those who are willing to follow established procedures and protocols.

title: Five fingers of evolution - Paul Andersen

title: Re-thinking progress: The circular economy

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the living world's cyclical model and the human approach to resource management?

options.label: B
options.text: The living world's model is cyclical, while humans adopt a linear approach.

options.label: C
options.text: The living world's model is based on energy from the Sun, while humans rely on fossil fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: The living world's model is based on biodegradable materials, while humans use non-biodegradable materials.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be sold to other companies.

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A new technology.

options.label: C

options.label: D
